title: Is the greatest common factor of 2 and 4 greater than 2? What is the GCF of 2, and 4? - Quora

response.answer_text: First of all, when we are discussing “numbers” and their factors, we mean “natural numbers.” The natural numbers are the counting numbers starting at 1.1,2,3,4,⋯1,2,3,4,⋯No fractions allowed! One number is a factor of another when the first number divides into the second number with no remainder. Every number is a factor of itself.All of the other factors are smaller than the number. A common factor of two (or more) numbers is a number that divides both of them (or all of them) with no remainder. It is a factor that they share, a factor that they have in common. The factors of 6 are 1, 2, 3, and 6.The factors of 9 are 1, 3, and 9. The common factors of 6 and 9 (the factors that they share) are 1 and 3. Now to your first question: Is the greatest common factor of 2 and 4 greater than 2? No number has a factor that is larger than itself, so the greatest common factor of 2 and 4 cannot be greater than 2.Answer: No. The greatest common factor of 2 and 4 is not greater than 2.Now your second question: What is the GCF of 2 and 4? “GCF” stands for Greatest Common Factor.The factors of 2 are 1 and 2.The factors of 4 are 1, 2, and 4.The greatest factor they share is 2.So the GCF of 2 and 4 is 2.Answer: 2

The greatest common factor (GCF) of a set of numbers is the largest factor that all the numbers share. For example, 12, 20, and 24 have two common factors: 2 and 4. The largest is 4, so we say that the GCF of 12, 20, and 24 is 4.
2 = 2×1 4 = 2×2×1 so, GCF of 4 and 2 = 2 and, 2 is not greater than 2 hence, the GCF of 2 and 4 is not greater than 2
